awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation Award: Seasonal Mobilization and Acid Stress Response of Opportunistic Enteric Pathogen Communities in Freshwater Ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities-Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) Research Initiation Awards (RIAs) provide support to STEM faculty at HBCUs including junior faculty who are starting to build a research program and mid-career faculty returning to the faculty ranks after holding an administrative post or who need to redirect and rebuild a research program. Faculty members may pursue research at their home institution, at an NSF-funded Center, at a research intensive institution or at a national laboratory. The RIA projects are expected to help further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, to improve research and teaching at his or her home institution, and to involve undergraduate students in research experiences. Paine College will conduct research on the role that rainfall plays in mobilizing bacterial pathogens which are linked to human health. The project will help build the research capacity at Paine College and will have a major impact on a large population of minority students. The research opportunities and modification of existing curricular offerings will provide undergraduate students with advanced skills in environmental science and enhance teaching and learning at Paine College. In addition, Paine College will enhance its outreach activities to the community by training students majoring in Education who will develop an online teaching module for high schools.  

The project will integrate water quality surveillance, microcosm studies, environmental sampling, traditional culturing and quantitative molecular analysis to assess the ecological implications of rainfall events on mobilization of four opportunistic enteric pathogens and elicitation of acid stress response (ASR) within a freshwater floodplain. The principle objectives are to: 1) characterize the role of rainfall events in mobilization of sediment associated bacterial communities into a seasonal wetland, and 2) characterize ASR elicitation of the bacterial community within a wetland and riverine system. Findings from this work will strengthen understanding of bacterial community structure and function in aquatic ecosystems, may aid in identification of seasonal environmental "hot spots" of bacterial pathogenicity and may transform paradigms of seasonally influenced bacterial diseases. This project has the potential to transform current mechanistic linkages of opportunistic pathogen mobilization into seasonal wetlands and the contributions of these aquatic ecosystems in conditioning bacterial pathogenicity and community structure.

por.por_cntn:
The HBCU-UP RIA project entitled "Research Initiation Award: Seasonal Mobilization and Acid Stress Response of Opportunistic Enteric Pathogen Communities in Freshwater Ecosystems" is yielding important outcomes relating to bacterial community composition and microbial ecology within select freshwater temporary wetlands and has been pivotal regarding student engagement and scholarly activities.  During this project, fecal coliform-like bacteria were detected in environmental water samples collected from freshwater temporary wetlands and were shown to be capable of sustained growth in the environmental water samples.  Additionally, select opportunistic enteric pathogens demonstrated an Acid Stress Response (ASR) when incubated in these environmental water samples.  Pre-conditioning the bacteria in the in situ sub-lethal pH (pH 5.7) of the collected wetland water samples was shown to enhance survival of bacteria upon exposure to extreme acid shock (pH 3.5).  The ASR observed among bacteria cultured in water samples collected from the temporary wetlands was equal to that observed for cultures grown in acid amended laboratory media and greater than that observed in bacteria cultured in freshwater control stream samples.  This suggests that the pre-lethal pH of the temporary wetlands elicits an ASR that enhances bacterial survival upon exposure to acidic conditions similar those that would be encountered in the mammalian host GI tract. 

Paine College is a small liberal arts HBCU located in Augusta, GA.  During the funding period, a total of thirteen undergraduate students enrolled at Paine College participated in this research project.  These students either received funds directly from this grant, acquired external fellowship grants for research related to this project or participated in independent research to satisfy requirements towards their undergraduate degree.  This grant provided funds for several of these students to travel to the ASM annual meetings where they were exposed to a broader range of STEM related research projects than is currently available at Paine College.  Many of the students prepared and presented posters for regional scientific conferences and for Research Day activities at Paine College and other HBCUs in Atlanta, GA.  Further, students prepared oral and written presentations of their research findings in defense of senior theses and as required for undergraduate fellowship programs.  A large majority of students who participated in this project and who graduated from Paine College with a degree in Biology or Chemistry, enrolled in and completed post-graduate degree programs in STEM related disciplines and continue to work in science-based professions.  

The techniques used in this project, including the molecular analysis techniques, have been incorporated into teaching modules in Introductory Biology curricula as well as upper level Microbiology and Ecology courses.  Plans are in place to introduce these teaching modules to a local high school and middle school.  One manuscript related to this project is in preparation for submission to a peer-review journal with an undergraduate student serving as a co-author.  This project facilitated interdisciplinary collaborations between Biology and Chemistry faculty and staff at Paine College.  Additional scientific collaborations have been sustained with the temporary wetland preserve, Reed Creek Park.  Lastly, this project has provided the students of Paine College hands on experience with research techniques and instrumentation that was absent from Paine College prior to this grant.  The instrumentation purchased through this grant is now housed in a designated molecular analysis lab and will provide important infrastructure for current and future research projects and educational purposes. 

This project is impactful in that it demonstrates a freshwater ecosystem capable of fostering bacterial growth and influencing the pathogenicity of a subset of clinically relevant opportunistic enteric pathogens.  Fecal coliform-like bacteria were detected in environmental freshwater samples and cultured on laboratory media and cultivation in the collected water samples was demonstrated to elicit the ASR as measured by survival rates of bacteria following an acid shock challenge.  This information is valuable to individuals on local and regional scales who rely on temporary wetlands for food, water and recreation purposes.  These findings aid in understanding the ecological impact of temporary wetlands on bacterial pathogenicity by demonstrating an environmental elicitation of the ASR.  

One behalf of myself, the students of Paine College and the Paine College community, I would like to thank the National Science Foundation for approving funding of this grant.

Modified by: Gabriel Swenson
